Graphical abstract The present study employed density-functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the Suzuki-Miyaura Cross-Coupling reaction using single atom catalysis (SAC) via palladium or nickel. The reaction barriers for chloride bond cleavage in phenyl chloride were found to be 34.68 kJ/mol and 24.24 kJ/mol for palladium and nickel catalysts, respectively. During the transmetalation process, the energy barrier for boronic acid release from phenyl trihydroxyboronate using SAC via palladium and SAC via nickel was calculated to be 74.17 kJ/mol and 65.22 kJ/mol, respectively. The results indicated that in the oxidative addition and transmetalation reactions, the SAC via nickel outperforms the SAC via palladium, while the SAC via palladium excels in the reductive elimination reaction. These findings suggest the effectiveness of a SAC via nickel as a substitute for SAC via palladium in the synthesis of biphenyls in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction. Keywords Suzuki Miyaura cross-coupling Palladium Nickel Phenyl chloride Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction SAC have made significant advancements in heterogeneous catalysis, expanding their applications beyond the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction. Their exceptional properties make them highly promising candidates for driving a diverse range of reactions. For instance, the performance of MoS 2 in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) can be significantly enhanced by doping it with specific elements such as carbon, boron, nitrogen, and phosphorus [1]. The development of new electrocatalysts for the efficient production of ammonia (NH 3 ) through the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) is also important. Notably, Mo-doped iron phosphide monolayers,Mo-doped Fe 3 P exhibit great potential as NRR electrocatalysts [2]. Another area that shows promise is the conversion of CO 2 into methanol using SAC. A study focusing on the use of a single Ruthenium (Ru) atom anchored on a MoS 2 monolayer as a SAC for CO 2 conversion has provided valuable insights into the design of more efficient CO 2 conversion catalysts [3]. Furthermore, tetragonal transition-metal phosphide monolayers, including Co 2 P, Ni 2 P, Ru 2 P, and Pd 2 P, hold potential as electrocatalysts for converting nitrate (NO 3 − ) into ammonia (NH 3 ) through the electrochemical NO 3 − reduction reaction (NO 3 RR). This process offers promise for reducing water pollution and providing a sustainable method for NH 3 synthesis at low temperatures [4]. Lastly, the utilization of SACs for converting harmful nitric oxide (NO) into ammonia (NH 3 ) through the electrochemical nitric oxide reduction reaction (NORR) presents an opportunity to simultaneously remove NO from the environment and produce valuable fertilizer [5] One of the most efficient procedures for synthesizing organic compounds is the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction, catalyzed by transition metals [6]. This reaction has the capability to produce polyolefins, styrene, and biphenyl derivatives, which find utility across chemical, natural product, pharmaceutical, and biochemical sectors [7–11]. Palladium or nickel-catalyzed Suzuki reactions involve the coupling of organoboron reagents with organic halides or pseudohalides under alkaline conditions [12,13]. The Suzuki-Miyaura reaction using a palladium catalyst is more widely employed due to its moderate reaction conditions, commercial availability of reagents, and ease of removing the boron byproducts [14]. Biphenyl can be synthesized using palladium and nickel-based catalysts for the C-C bond formation reaction involving aryl halides and arylboronic acid [15]. In the Suzuki Cross-Coupling reaction, aryl chlorides are preferred over halobenzenes due to their greater accessibility and environmental friendliness [16]. Moreover, aryl halides exhibit the following reactivity order: A r − I > A r − B r > A r − C l Therefore, it is important to take into account the dissociation energy of the C-X bond when considering these reactions [17]. The use of complexes and ligands in palladium poses challenges due to their high cost and potential toxicity [18]. Efforts to develop heterogeneous catalysts for the Suzuki Cross-Coupling reaction involve the utilization of a single-atom structure to provide strong electron donation [19]. Palladium-based catalysts exhibit good role in carbon-carbon bond formation, with palladium serving as a catalytic atom, which important for facilitating cross-coupling reactions [20–23]. The palladium catalyst approach for the ligand-free Suzuki reaction continues to be pursued due to the high cost of palladium complexes and the challenges associated with catalyst recovery. This approach offers benefits such as recyclability, cost-effectiveness, sustainability, and broad industrial applicability [24,25]. In support of the heterogeneous catalysts development, the catalyst may contain metal clusters as the active centers. This configuration can mitigate cluster erosion and sintering processes, leading to an increased catalytic activity and reduced production costs [26]. The nickel catalyst in the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction exhibits favourable interaction with various functional groups, owing to its selectivity. However, the selectivity of palladium is governed by the electronic properties of aryl halides [27]. Additionally, nickel possesses low electronegativity and a low potential for gaining electrons, which leads to an easier oxidation process [28]. Nickel nanoparticles (Ni-NPs) hold significant promise as efficient and reusable catalysts for the synthesis of organic compounds and biological activities [29–31]. The development of the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction was pursued using both palladium and nickel as catalysts. In this study, we aim to elucidate the fundamental catalytic behavior of nickel, which will enable us to compare it to palladium in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction for biphenyl production. This simplified system enables a more controlled comparison with palladium, ultimately guiding us towards potentially optimizing the Suzuki reaction for enhanced biphenyl production. 2 Material and methods In this study, the mechanism of the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction begins with the process of oxidative addition, in which the aryl chloride reacts with either palladium (Pd) or nickel (Ni) catalyst, denoted as X, resulting in the formation of R1-X-Cl. Following this, transmetalation takes place between the aryl borate and R1-X-Cl, thereby facilitating the substitution of the chloride group with the R group from the aryl borate. Finally, the reductive elimination step occurs which produces the biphenyl product (R1-R2) (Fig. 1 ). All adopted molecular structures were optimized at the DFT level. The B3LYP hybrid exchange-correlation density functional [30], combined with the Grimme D4 empirical dispersion correction (DFT-D4) [32] and def2-TZVP basis set [33], were utilized to perform the geometry optimization and calculated the thermodynamic properties. The Gibbs free energies were calculated by the summation of the electronic, zero-point, and thermal energies obtained from the frequency calculations at 298.15 K. The TDDFT/B3LYP-D4/def2-TZVP method was employed to calculate the HOMO-LUMO orbital. The electronic properties of the molecule was assessed by calculating the electrostatic potential (ESP) charges by using the Multiwfn code [34]. All DFT calculations were performed using the ORCA software package [35]. The visualizations were done by using Chemcraft [36] and Cylview [37]. 3 Results and discussion SAC offer great potential in the advancement of highly efficient and specific Suzuki-Miyaura catalysts. Thus, this study aimed to confirm the role of SAC in each of the three key stages of the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction: oxidative addition, transmetalation, and reductive elimination. This will emphasize the importance of SACs for each step in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction. 3.1 Oxidative addition stage The mechanism of the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction, involving a single-atom catalyst, offer advantages in terms of catalytic activities, selectivity, and reaction efficiency [38]. In general, the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling mechanism, consists of three steps of elementary reactions, namely, the oxidative addition, transmetalation, and reductive elimination [39]. In this first elementary reaction, the oxidative addition that begins with the coordination of C–Cl σ -bond to the metal atom takes place, forming the intermediate A. As shown in Fig. 2 , in addition to the coordinated σ -bond, the π -bond between C-C of the phenyl group also exists in the intermediate A. As also shown in Fig. 2, the addition reaction is exergonic with the Gibbs free energy of − 67.30 and − 142.04 kJ/mol for paladium and nickel metal, respectively. Similar exergonic nature for such an addition reaction was also reported in the previous work [40]. The addition reaction with the nickel catalyst exhibits a lower Gibbs free energy, indicating that the addition process for the nickel catalyst is thermodynamically more favorable than that of palladium catalyst. Starting from intermediate A, chloride is released from phenyl chloride when it’s adsorbed on single-atom palladium and nickel catalysts. In Transition State (TS1), An activation energy is observed with a nickel catalyst, around 24.24 kJ/mol, accompanied by a change in bond length. At first, the C–Cl bond in intermediate A is about 1.78 Å, and then it stretches to approximately 1.99 Å in TS1 before finally reaching 3.16 Å in intermediate B. Furthermore, the relativistic effect was incorporated by employing the zeroth-order regular approximation (ZORA). The calculated Gibbs activation energy after incorporating ZORA is 25.82 kJ/mol, slightly higher than that of without incorporating the relativistic effect, namely, 24.27 kJ/mol, as shown in Fig. 3 . Relativistic effects in TS1 with a palladium catalyst do not influence changes in the C–Cl bond length. Changes in C–Cl bond length occur in intermediate A, for about 1.78 Å. As bond distance increases, the covalent bond becomes prone to the chemical reaction [41]. It leads to a lower activation energy in TS1 when the relativistic effects are considered. As shown in Fig. 5 that when HOMO and LUMO energies are close, the electron is excited from HOMO to LUMO, thus in this case there is an increase in chloride density from intermediate A to intermediate B, which causes a shift in density due to the presence of the nickel catalyst. Furthermore, the ESP charge calculations were performed using the B3LYP functional and the cc-pVTZ-DK basis set in order to investigate the erlectronic properties of the molecules. It has been observed that charge of the nickel atom in intermediates A and B is + 0.266 and + 0.572 , respectively, thus A to B conversion increases the charge of the nickel atom. This change is due to the electron transfer to the chlorine atom. Meanwhile, the charge of the Cl atom in intermediate A is − 0.255 , and in intermediate B, it is − 0.448 , resulting in an electron transfer from nickel to aryl chloride of + 0.306 . The release of chloride causes carbon electrons that were bonded to nickel to redistribute towards chlorine atoms. This redistribution leads to the breaking of the bond between the chlorine atom and benzene. As shown in Fig. 2, the use of a palladium catalyst results in an activation energy of 34.68 kJ/mol and an increase in the C–Cl bond length. The initial bond length was 1.77 Å, which expanded to 2.02 Å and 3.06 Å from intermediate A to TS1. Interestingly, the inclusion of relativistic effects reduces the energy barrier from 34.68 to 31.77 kJ/mol, as shown in Fig. 3. This reduction in the energy barrier corresponds to a change in the bond length of C–Cl bond to 1.94 Å in TS1, indicating that a shorter bond length makes it more challenging to break the bond between the atoms. As shown in Fig. 4 , the palladium catalyst exhibits a noticeable change in the lobe size on the chlorine atom from intermediate A to intermediate B, resulting in a shift in the probability density of the chloride atom. The charge on palladium in intermediate A is approximately + 0.304 , but it increases to around + 0.567 , showing a more positive charge on palladium in this state. Meanwhile, the charge on chloride is around + 0.269 in intermediate A and − 0.471 in intermediate B. This indicates a charge polarization from chloride to palladium, resulting in a more negative charge on chloride and a more positive charge on palladium. This change is due to an electron charge transfer of + 0.263 . These calculations in the oxidative addition stage showed that the activation energy is lower when using a nickel catalyst compared to a palladium catalyst. 3.2 Transmetalation stage The second step of the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction entails transmetalation, during intermediate B (Ph-Pd-Cl) directly undergoes transmetalation with the activated-base atomic complex Ph-B(OH) 3 resulting in the formation of intermediate D, as illustred in Fig. 6 . Intermediate B on the nickel catalyst experiences a reduction in energy by − 263.42 kJ/mol as shown in Fig. 6. Subsequently, the transmetalation step involves the transfer of organic groups from the organoboron species to the palladium complex, which has undergone oxidative addition with the aryl halide. Additionally, phenylboronic acid coordinates with nickel to form intermediate C, resulting in an energy increase of − 208.02 kJ/mol on the nickel catalyst. The subsequent step entails the release of the B(OH) 3 group from the phenyl ring, leading to the formation of intermediate D. The transition state in TS2 with nickel catalysts involves the release of the B(OH) 3 group with an activation energy of 65.22 kJ/mol. The bond distance between boron on phenyl and the nickel catalyst increases from 1.66 Å to 3.46 Å. Fig. 7 , the influence of relativistic effects also impacts the activation energy value of 92.13 kJ/mol. With the relativistic effect, the bond length in TS2 is 1.82 Å, whereas without the relativistic effect, the bond length remains 1.85 Å. Fig. 8 shows the change in HOMO-LUMO density using a nickel catalyst in intermediate D, resulting in a decrease in the density around the boric acid group. The charge on nickel shifts to increasingly negative values from intermediate C to intermediate D; with intermediate C having a charge of + 0.705 and intermediate D having a charge of 0.670. Additionally, there is a transfer of charge of 0.333 between the boric acid and the palladium complex. As a results, the boric acid group becomes more positively charged due to electron loss. In the case of the palladium catalyst as shown in Fig. 6, intermediate B similarly experiences a decrease in energy by − 104.07 kJ/mol. Following this, intermediate B progresses to the formation of intermediate C, wherein phenylboronic acid coordinates with palladium, resulting in an energy increase of − 38.08 kJ/mol in the palladium catalyst. The subsequent step involves the liberation of the B(OH) 3 group, giving rise to intermediate D. The transition state corresponding to the release of the B(OH) 3 group, denoted as TS2, showcases an activation energy of 74.17 kJ/mol in the palladium catalyst. The change in the boron-to-phenyl bond distance using the palladium catalyst increases from 1.66 Å to 3.57 Å. The impact of the relativistic effect (Fig. 7) also influences the activation energy by 103.01 kJ/mol, resulting in the bond length within the TS2 intermediate measuring 1.87 Å when the relativistic effect is present. However, without the relativistic effect, the bond length is 1.88 Å. Furthernore, as shown in Fig. 9 , the levels of HOMO-LUMO density using the palladium catalyst in intermediate D showing a decrease within the borate acid group. Subsequently, the charge on palladium shifts towards increasingly negative values from intermediate C to intermediate D, namely, with the partial charges of + 0.762 and 0.657 in intermediates C and D, respectively. The charge transfer between the boric acid and the palladium complex, amounting to + 0.330 , results in the boric acid group becoming more positively charged due to the loss of electrons 3.3 Reductive elimination stage (Formation of Carbon-Carbon Bonds) After the transmetalation step, the palladium-catalyzed Suzuki-Miyaura reaction undergoes reductive elimination. This process leads to the creation of a new C–C bond between the two organic groups within the palladium complex. The reductive elimination phase initiates with the transmetalation product, where the intermediate F represents the loss of the B(OH) 3 group. The energy of the intermediate F on the palladium catalyst is -135.71 kJ/mol, and its C–C bond distance of 2.83 Å, as shown in Fig. 10 . Subsequently, palladium progresses toward the transition state of carbon-carbon bond formation. TS2 shows the coupling of C–C bonds, leading to the formation of intermediate G, where the C–Pd bond in one of the phenyl groups is broken. In intermediate G, palladium has 8 free electrons, thus it can only accept a pair of free electrons. Palladium is more effective in bonding with a single atom rather than two, resulting in the formation of a phi bond between the C–C bonds and the Pd catalyst in intermediate G. The phi bond occurs because two P orbitals overlap in benzene, forming the electron density between the palladium or nickel catalyst and intermediate G. The formation of C–C bonds to produce biphenyl products has a barrier energy of 42.48 kJ/mol with a palladium catalyst. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 10, the relativistic effect found a value of 53.23 kJ/mol which is associated with a C–C bond distance of 2.06 Å in TS3 and a bond length of 2.92 Å in intermediate E. In contrast, in the absence of relativistic effects, TS3 shows a bond length of 2.06 Å, while intermediate E has a C–C bond distance of 2.83 Å. As shown in Fig. 12, we observed a gradual increase in the homo-lumo density level from intermediate E to Intermediate F with palladium which indicated that there is an electron transfer. In intermediate E, palladium has a charge of + 0.483 , which decreases to + 0.204 in intermediate F, indicating more negative charge on palladium. This observation also suggests that from intermediate F to intermediate E, there is a charge transfer around + 0.279 from biphenyl to palladium. In intermediate E, the nickel catalyst can bind with two phenyl groups. Then, the C-Ni bond in one of the phenyl groups breaks, leading to the formation of a carbon-carbon bond, known as intermediate F, with a certain amount of energy − 248.00 kJ/mol.The process of forming intermediate F requires an activation energy of 51.97 kJ/mol, as seen in Fig. 10. Moreover, when we consider the impact of relativistic effects, as shown in Fig. 11 , the activation energy remains at 67.26 kJ/mol, and the bond distance at TS3 is 1.83 Å. There is a difference in bond length between intermediate E, where the C–C bond distance is 2.92 Å, and when there are no relativistic effects, it’s 2.54 Å. This variation in bond length leads to the difference in activation energy at TS3. The formation of C–C bonds is also influenced by an increased electron density in the HOMO-LUMO transition between intermediates E and F. This is reflected in the changing charge on the nickel catalyst, which becomes increasingly negative, as shown in Fig. 13 . The nickel charge in intermediate E is + 0.445 , while in intermediate F, the nickel atom carries a charge of + 0.259 . Therefore, there is a transfer of charge of + 0.186 from biphenyl to the nickel catalyst, indicating an electron transfer. As shown in Fig. 14 show that the result of the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction is biphenyl. This resulting product exhibits a non-flat structure, forming a slightly curved, or bent, configuration with dihedral angles between the rings, as mentioned in references [42,43]. In our research, we found that the molecule biphenyl forms a dihedral angle of 39 . 19 ∘ after undergoing optimization calculations, as shown in Fig. 14. Palladium has an electron configuration of [Kr] 4d 10 5s 0 , which means it has no unpaired electrons in its ground state, resulting in a multiplicity of 1 or singlet. Nickel, on the other hand, has an electron configuration of [Ar] 3d 8 4s 2 [44]. In its ground state, nickel has two unpaired electrons in the 3d orbital. These unpaired electrons in nickel provide different stability and catalytic reactivity in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions. As shown in Table 1 , the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction involves three consecutive stages. The first stage is called oxidative addition, where our calculations suggest that using a nickel catalyst requires less activation energy compared to using a palladium catalyst. This finding is quite important. The second stage is transmetalation, which is essentially the critical step determining the speed and efficiency of the carbon-carbon coupling reaction [45,46]. This stage is highly significant in this context, and prior research [47] highlights the central role of transmetalation in controlling the rate of the carbon-carbon coupling reaction. The table above shows that the palladium catalyst has an activation energy of 74.17 kJ/mol, which is higher than the nickel catalyst’s activation energy of 65.22 kJ/mol. The final step involves forming carbon-carbon bonds or a reductive elimination to produce biphenyl as the product. The activation energy with the nickel catalyst is 51.98 kJ/mol, while with the palladium catalyst, it’s 42.48 kJ/mol. This stage suggests that the nickel catalyst is better at forming carbon-carbon bonds. In light of the complete reaction, the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction with nickel and palladium catalysts resulted in a reaction enthalpy of -313.616 kJ/mol, indicating the exothermic nature of the process. 3.4 HOMO-LUMO analysis In Fig. 15 , we have observed the band gap for each reaction, under consideration using both nickel and palladium catalysts. When the nickel catalyst is employed, we observe that the smallest band gap is approximately 163.57 kJ/mol in the biphenyl product, and the largest band gap is found at around 378.597 kJ/mol in intermediate E. Moreover, when the palladium catalyst is used, the band gap for the biphenyl product is larger, at around 248.110 kJ/mol, and the largest band gap was found to be approximately 424.281 kJ/mol in intermediate D. The resulting biphenyl compound exhibits a curved structure with dihedral angles between its rings [42,43]. These findings suggest that the nickel catalyst is more reactive than the palladium catalyst. This implies that electron excitation from the HOMO to the LUMO in the biphenyl product occurs more readily when using the nickel catalyst, compared to the palladium catalyst. 4 Summary In this study, we have observed that the nickel catalyst is better than the palladium catalyst in both the oxidative addition and transmetalation stages of the reaction. The rate-determining step of the reaction is the transmetalation step, with an activation energy of 65.22 kJ/mol for nickel catalysts and 74.17 kJ/mol for palladium catalysts showing the nickel catalysts being more efficient than palladium catalysts. Our proposed reaction mechanism holds promise for practical implementation is feasible due to the favorable thermodynamic characteristics observed throughout most of the reaction steps. coredata.dc:description: The present study employed density-functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the Suzuki-Miyaura Cross-Coupling reaction using single atom catalysis (SAC) via palladium or nickel. The reaction barriers for chloride bond cleavage in phenyl chloride were found to be 34.68 kJ/mol and 24.24 kJ/mol for palladium and nickel catalysts, respectively. During the transmetalation process, the energy barrier for boronic acid release from phenyl trihydroxyboronate using SAC via palladium and SAC via nickel was calculated to be 74.17 kJ/mol and 65.22 kJ/mol, respectively. The results indicated that in the oxidative addition and transmetalation reactions, the SAC via nickel outperforms the SAC via palladium, while the SAC via palladium excels in the reductive elimination reaction. These findings suggest the effectiveness of a SAC via nickel as a substitute for SAC via palladium in the synthesis of biphenyls in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Exploring the energetics of Suzuki cross-coupling reaction: A computational study of palladium and nickel catalysts
